I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The Green and Resilient Affordable Housing Sector Project (the project) is proposed to be 
financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The project, which will be implemented during 
2021–2027, aims to support the Government of Bhutan’s efforts to implement the National 
Housing Policy, 2020 (NHP).1 The objectives of the NHP include (i) providing safe, affordable, 
and adequate rental housing for all; (ii) promoting home ownership; (iii) encouraging partnership 
and cooperation among private and government entities; and (iv) promoting green and energy-
efficient housing. To support the project, ADB will provide a concessional loan of $24 million from 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources, and a grant of $6 million from ADB’s Special Funds resources 
(Asian  Development  Fund). 2  The  executing  agency  is  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  the 
implementing agency is the National Housing Development Corporation Limited (NHDCL). The 
project will be aligned with the following impact: livability, safety, and sustainability of human 
settlements ensured.3 
 
2.  The housing supply is unable to meet the increased demand for serviced land and housing, 
and house prices and rents are rising—making housing unaffordable for low-income households. 
Low-income civil servants who earn Nu900 to Nu3,500 per month face rental stress as they spend 
more than 40% of their income on housing.4 The government, with the financial support of ADB 
and through the NHDCL, will provide about 1,000 serviced rental units to civil servants and non-
civil servants, including marginalized municipal waste workers, with an affordable pricing objective 
to ensure that expenditures on housing do not exceed 30%. Further, the Asian Development Fund 
grant will support the promotion of the Sustainable Development Goal 5 transformative gender 
agenda by pilot-testing integrated service centers and livelihood initiatives to address gender 
issues. The project will cover nine locations across six districts—Nganglam (1 subproject), 
Phuentsholing (3 subprojects), Samdrup Jongkhar (2 subprojects), Thimphu (1 subproject), 
Trashiyangtse (1 subproject), and Samtse (1 subproject) with the potential for replication in 
additional subprojects to be funded under the sector loan or in a subsequent phase. The project 
is expected to benefit 1,000 households directly, by putting families, including vulnerable groups 
such as women and youth, into rental homes. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The government has requested ADB support to help implement the project. To support 
the project implementation, the transaction technical assistance (TA) will assist, to effectively 
implement the project. The TA objectives are to (i) strengthen the NHP and review land availability, 
land management, and land-use planning; (ii) mainstream resilience considerations in the housing 
development process, and promote the use of innovative construction technology and practices; 
(iii) establish a housing MIS; and (iv) provide technical support to the NHDCL on the project’s  
safeguard compliance. Specifically, the TA will provide technical advisory support services to the 
NHDCL (i) to review and update its allotment rules and regulations to ensure consistency with the 
NHP, and (ii) to monitor costs and target the uptake of new rental housing by low-income groups. 
It will also support the NHDCL in monitoring and reporting on the achievement of the project

design and monitoring framework performance indicators, in addition to ensuring that the project 
safeguards are effectively managed. The TA will also support the Ministry of Works and Human 
Settlement (MOWHS) in improving the policy framework, strengthening regulatory frameworks 
that are beyond the remit of the NHDCL, strengthening the capacity and systems to manage the 
project effectively, and implementing the housing management information system (MIS). The 
ADB team discussed the scope of the TA with the NHDCL during the fact-finding mission in June–
August 2021.5 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  Output 1: Housing policy and land management improved. The TA will support the 
executing and implementing agencies to  
(i)  review and formulate the updated NHP (emphasizing green building principles and 
climate and disaster risk reduction measures); 
(ii)  prepare a housing information management proposal, including land and property 
information; and 
(iii)  review the housing value chain (e.g., mortgage lending, subsidy arrangements, 
potential  for  a  housing  fund,  and  housing  construction,  and  operation  and 
maintenance). 
 
5.  Output 2: Resilience of beneficiaries consolidated. The TA will help 
(i)  review and update the national building code; 
(ii)  raise awareness and build capacity on climate- and disaster-resilient housing 
designs, standards, and relevant code provisions; encourage resilient building 
practices; and provide support to vulnerable households; and 
(iii)  standardize training and capacity building for engineers, architects, planners, and 
tradespeople across the construction and housing sector. 
 
6.  Output 3: Housing management information system established. The TA will  
(i)  strengthen the capacity and knowledge of the MOWHS on the analytical tools 
required for an effective housing provider implementation strategy and for meeting 
sector needs; 
(ii)  design and implement a housing MIS; and 
(iii)  train the NHDCL and the MOWHS to use the housing MIS. 
 
7.  Output 4: Safeguards management system strengthened. The TA will assist NHDCL to  
(i)  set up a safeguard unit within the NHDCL; 
(ii)  prepare and implement operational safeguard management guidelines; and 
(iii)  provide awareness building activities and training to promote environment and social 
safeguard implementation and compliance. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
8.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.1 million, of which $1.0 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–7). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 1.  
 
 
5 The TA is included in the ADB. Forthcoming. Indicative Country Pipeline and Monitoring Report: Bhutan, 2022–2024. 
Manila. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 9 December 2020.

9.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space for consultants, access to data and information for international and national consultants, 
and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB will administer the TA. ADB’s South Asia Department will select, supervise, and 
evaluate the consultants; and procure goods.
